text:
Mike Pence Visits Vandalized Jewish Cemetery, Helps Clean Up “We condemn this vile act of vandalism ..." by Charles Campbell February 23, 2017 at 1:10pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
After more than 150 headstones were vandalized at a Jewish cemetery in Missouri, Vice President Mike Pence visited the scene to both condemn the actions and offer his help. 
Pence was photographed helping restore what was damaged, side by side Missouri Governor Eric Greitens and other volunteers. VP Pence and Gov Greitens also pitch in for a few minutes to help clean up the desecrated cemetery. pic.twitter.com/DcGnqfZyXW 
— Mark Knoller (@markknoller) February 22, 2017 Advertisement - story continues below Report: Bannon, Pence Deliver Different Messages About Trump’s EU Policies 
“We condemn this vile act of vandalism and those who perpetrate it in the strongest possible terms,” Pence told the crowd gathered at the cemetery, before recalling his recent visit to a concentration camp in Dachau, Germany. “We saw firsthand what happens when hatred runs rampant in a society.” 
“It’s been inspiring to people all across this country to see the way the people of Missouri have rallied around the Jewish community with compassion and support,” the vice president added. “You have inspired this nation with your kindness and your care.” Advertisement – story continues below 
Pence uploaded a picture to his Twitter account, thanking those who helped cleanup. MO's people are inspiring the nation w/ their compassion for the Jewish community. Thank you for showing the world what America is all about pic.twitter.com/PWTFLGqqz0 
— Vice President Pence (@VP) February 22, 2017 
“There is no place in America for hatred or acts of prejudice or violence or anti-Semitism,” he said. “You just make us all proud.” Advertisement - story continues below ICE: More Than 950,000 Illegal Immigrants With Active Deportation Orders At Large 
Pence was also seen bowing his head as the local rabbi offered prayers for those gathered. 
Many Jewish groups were pleased with Pence’s condemnation of the recent spate of anti-Semitic activities. One notable group, the Anne Frank Center for Mutual Respect, thanked Pence on their Facebook page. 
“THANK YOU, VICE-PRESIDENT PENCE, FOR VISITING AND CLEANING THE DESECRATED JEWISH GRAVES IN ST. LOUIS,” the group wrote. 
Steven Goldstein, executive director of the Anne Frank Center, said he still condemned President Donald Trump’s insensitivity towards Jews, but acknowledged that Pence was setting the right example. 
“Vice President Pence proved to be the ultimate mensch by visiting, and even cleaning, the desecrated Jewish graves in St. Louis,” Goldstein wrote in a statement. “Make no mistake: We have been critical of President Trump for his gross insensitivity to Antisemitism, including through his omission of Jews in Holocaust remembrance. But through the Vice President’s visit to St. Louis today, this Administration finally showed America the kind of response our nation was waiting for all along — a response filled with proactive heart.” What do you think?
